title: Making Inferences
subtitle: Reading Between the Lines
learning_objectives: The Core: Master logical inferences from textual evidence
The Skill: Take exactly one step beyond what's stated
The Problem: Distinguish between logical conclusions and overreaching assumptions
Key Strategy: The 3-Phase INFER Strategy for 100% provable inferences

content.heading: PHASE 1: Read Literally First
content.subtitle: What Does the Passage Actually State?

core_principle.title: The Foundation Rule
core_principle.description: Valid inferences build on explicit statements. Before inferring anything, identify exactly what the passage DOES say.

strategy_steps.title: Identify Explicit Statements
strategy_steps.description: What facts does the passage directly state?

examples.text: Sarah checked her watch for the third time and tapped her foot impatiently.
examples.explicit: Sarah checked watch (3 times), tapped foot
examples.not_explicit: Why she's doing this, what she's waiting for, her personality

examples.text: The funding was cut after eight years of research. Dr. Martinez spent three months writing grant proposals. Only one of twelve applications succeeded.
examples.explicit: Funding cut, 8 years research, 3 months on grants, 1/12 success
examples.not_explicit: How she feels, whether she'll continue, if the work is important

strategy_steps.title: Separate Facts from Interpretations
strategy_steps.description: Distinguish what's stated from what you're inferring

comparison.note: The inference is reasonable but goes beyond stated fact

comparison.stated: She spent every weekend there for six months
comparison.inference: She was dedicated/committed to the project
comparison.note: Dedication is inferred from consistent action

strategy_steps.title: Note What's NOT Said
strategy_steps.description: Be aware of information gaps—don't fill them with assumptions

example.text: The experiment failed; however, the data was still valuable.
example.what_we_know: Experiment didn't succeed, data has value
example.what_we_dont_know: Why it failed, what they expected, what they'll do next, how valuable the data is

content.key_insight: Solid inferences require solid foundations. If you can't point to specific evidence for each part of an inference, it's probably overreach.

core_principle.title: The SAT Inference Standard
core_principle.description: Valid SAT inferences require exactly ONE logical step from stated evidence. Multiple-step reasoning chains are always wrong.

one_step_examples.evidence: Sarah checked her watch for the third time and tapped her foot impatiently.
one_step_examples.one_step_inference: Sarah is waiting for something/someone and feeling impatient
one_step_examples.why_valid: Checking watch repeatedly + impatient action = one logical step to conclusion about waiting
one_step_examples.overreach: Sarah is always impatient / Sarah has anxiety / Sarah's meeting is important
one_step_examples.why_overreach: Requires multiple steps or outside knowledge beyond what's stated

one_step_examples.evidence: After eight years, funding was cut. Dr. Martinez spent three months writing grants. Only 1 of 12 applications succeeded.
one_step_examples.one_step_inference: Securing research funding was difficult and competitive
one_step_examples.why_valid: Low success rate (1/12) + time investment (3 months) = directly indicates difficulty
one_step_examples.overreach: Dr. Martinez will give up / The research wasn't important / Funding agencies are unfair
one_step_examples.why_overreach: Goes beyond evidence—assumes future actions, value judgments, or causation

one_step_examples.evidence: Maria walked through the empty theater and immediately began sketching renovation plans. She spent every weekend there for six months.
one_step_examples.one_step_inference: Maria has a vision for the theater and is actively pursuing it
one_step_examples.why_valid: Immediate planning + consistent presence = shows intent and commitment
one_step_examples.overreach: Maria will definitely succeed / Maria has unlimited funds / Maria is a professional renovator
one_step_examples.why_overreach: Predicts future, assumes resources, or adds details not in passage

the_step_test.title: How to Verify 'One Step'
questions: Can I draw a direct line from evidence to conclusion?
Does this require assuming additional facts not in the passage?
Am I making one inference or chaining multiple inferences together?
Would someone reading ONLY the passage reach this same conclusion?
red_flags: If you need to think 'well, if this, then that, which means...' → too many steps
If you're using outside knowledge (how funding works, what theaters cost) → wrong
If you're predicting the future (what will happen) → usually overreach
If inference uses extreme language (always, never, all, none) → likely wrong

valid_vs_invalid.evidence: Scientists worldwide are studying bioluminescence to develop new biotechnologies.
valid_vs_invalid.invalid: Bioluminescence will revolutionize technology / All scientists study bioluminescence
valid_vs_invalid.why: Valid stays close to text (studying for applications). Invalid adds certainty/scope not stated.

valid_vs_invalid.evidence: Despite facing discrimination, Curie's meticulous research earned worldwide recognition.
valid_vs_invalid.valid: Curie overcame obstacles through quality work
valid_vs_invalid.invalid: Discrimination prevented Curie from achieving more / All scientists faced discrimination
valid_vs_invalid.why: Valid reflects stated facts. Invalid distorts (passage says she DID succeed despite discrimination).

elements.reveal: If you have to think really hard about why an answer might be right, it's probably wrong. Valid inferences feel almost obvious—they're the natural conclusion from stated evidence.

trap_types.definition: Answers using absolute terms rarely supported by passages
trap_types.why_wrong: Passages rarely provide evidence for absolute claims—they discuss specific situations

examples.evidence: One scientist's experiment succeeded after years of work
examples.wrong: All scientists who work hard succeed

examples.evidence: Urban gardens reduced crime in some Detroit neighborhoods

trap_types.how_to_spot: If you think 'X suggests Y, which means Z' → too many steps

examples.one_step: Character feels anxiety about the presentation
examples.why_overreach: Step 1: nervous before presentation → Step 2: pattern of anxiety → Step 3: clinical diagnosis (3 steps)

trap_types.definition: Uses information not provided in the passage
trap_types.why_wrong: SAT tests reading comprehension, not general knowledge

examples.wrong_inference: Rome used advanced military tactics typical of the era
examples.why_wrong: Requires knowing Roman history—not stated in passage

examples.wrong_inference: Vertical farms are better because water scarcity is a global crisis
examples.why_wrong: Water scarcity context not in passage—using outside knowledge

trap_types.definition: Twists or reverses what passage actually states

examples.passage_says: Despite facing discrimination, Curie ultimately succeeded
examples.why_wrong: Passage says OPPOSITE—she succeeded despite discrimination

examples.passage_says: Initial challenges were addressed through recent advances

questions.question: Is this one step from stated evidence?
Can I point to specific text supporting EVERY part of this?
questions.if_no: Eliminate—uses outside knowledge or adds unsupported details

slides.title: Guided Practice: The Strategy in Action

content.heading: Let's Apply All 3 Phases Together
content.passage: Dr. Martinez had been working on the enzyme research for eight years when the funding was suddenly cut. She spent the next three months writing grant proposals and reaching out to private foundations. Despite submitting twelve applications, only one small foundation responded positively, offering just enough funding to continue for six more months.
content.question: The passage most strongly suggests that Dr. Martinez:

walkthrough.question: What does the passage explicitly state?
walkthrough.answer: Facts: 8 years work, funding cut, 3 months writing grants, 12 applications, 1 success, 6 months funding
walkthrough.reasoning: These are directly stated—no interpretation needed

walkthrough.question: What can we infer from '8 years work' + 'continued writing grants after cut'?
walkthrough.answer: She's committed to/invested in this research
walkthrough.reasoning: One step: lengthy dedication + persistence after setback = commitment

walkthrough.question: What can we infer from '1 success out of 12 applications'?
walkthrough.reasoning: One step: low success rate = competitive environment

walkthrough.question: Evaluate answer choices using trap patterns

options_analysis.text: is deeply committed to her research despite facing significant funding challenges
options_analysis.trap_check: Extreme language? No. Multiple steps? No. Outside knowledge? No. Supported? Yes (8 years + persistence + difficulty)
options_analysis.analysis: ✓ CORRECT—One step from evidence. 'Deeply committed' from 8 years + continued effort. 'Significant challenges' from 1/12 success.

options_analysis.text: will definitely complete her research within the six-month funding period
options_analysis.analysis: ✗ Overreach—passage gives no information about whether she'll complete. 'Definitely' is extreme language.

options_analysis.text: always struggles to secure funding for her projects
options_analysis.analysis: ✗ 'Always' unsupported—passage discusses only THIS research. Generalizes beyond evidence.

options_analysis.text: should have applied to more foundations to secure adequate funding
options_analysis.analysis: ✗ Makes judgment about what she 'should' do—not supported. Uses outside knowledge about how many applications is enough.

slides.title: Your Turn: Apply the INFER Strategy

content.heading: Independent Practice
content.instructions: Use all 3 phases: Read Literally → Take One Step → Eliminate Overreach
content.passage: The old theater had been empty for two decades, its velvet seats gathering dust and its stage dark. When Maria first walked through the lobby, she immediately began sketching renovation plans on the back of an envelope. She spent every weekend there for the next six months, measuring rooms and researching restoration techniques. Local craftsmen started recognizing her, and several offered to work for reduced rates.
content.question: The passage most strongly suggests that Maria:
content.strategy_reminder: Phase 1: What's explicitly stated? Phase 2: What's one step away? Phase 3: Check for extreme language, multiple steps, outside knowledge.

options: Is a professional theater renovator who always works alone
Has a vision for restoring the theater and is taking concrete steps toward that goal
Will definitely succeed in reopening the theater within a year
Has unlimited financial resources for the renovation project
content.explanation:
Let's apply the 3 phases:

PHASE 1—Stated facts:
- Theater empty 20 years
- Maria sketched plans immediately
- Consistent weekend visits (6 months)
- Measured/researched restoration
- Craftsmen recognize her, offer reduced rates

PHASE 2—One-step inferences:
- Immediate sketching = has vision/plan
- Consistent presence = commitment
- Measuring/researching = taking concrete action
- Craftsman support = making progress

PHASE 3—Eliminate traps:

A: ✗ EXTREME + OUTSIDE KNOWLEDGE—'professional' and 'always works alone' not stated. Makes assumptions about her career.

B: ✓ CORRECT—One step: immediate plans + consistent action = vision + concrete steps. No extreme language, fully supported.

C: ✗ FUTURE PREDICTION + EXTREME—'definitely' and 'within a year' unsupported. Passage doesn't predict success or timeline.

D: ✗ OUTSIDE KNOWLEDGE + ASSUMPTION—'unlimited resources' not stated or implied. Reduced rates might suggest opposite.

content.heading: Master These Traps—Avoid Overreach Every Time

rows: Always, never, all, none, every, only, must, certainly
Requires chain: X means Y, which means Z
Stop at first logical step from evidence
Rome expanded → 'used tactics typical of era'
Point to specific text for every claim
Twists or reverses what passage says
Check that inference matches passage direction

content.expert_insight: Valid inferences feel almost obvious—they're the natural, reasonable conclusion from stated evidence. If you're working hard to justify an answer, it's probably wrong.

content.heading: Inference Mastery
key_points: Phase 1: Read literally first—identify exactly what's stated before inferring anything
Phase 2: Take one logical step from evidence—never chain multiple inferences
Phase 3: Eliminate extreme language, multiple-step reasoning, outside knowledge, and distortions
The 100% Rule: Valid inferences are one step away, feel obvious, and point to specific textual support
content.strategy_reminder: Remember INFER: Identify explicit statements, Note what's one step away, Find the evidence, Eliminate extreme/multiple-step options, Reach the most reasonable conclusion
content.expert_insight: The most reasonable inference wins, not the most creative. If you're thinking 'Well, maybe if...' then you're probably overreaching.

practice_transition.text: Ready to apply your mastery? Let's practice with authentic SAT inference questions!

content.message: Outstanding! You've mastered making logical inferences with surgical precision.

slides.title: Mastery Check
slides.question: A passage states: 'Despite submitting her application two weeks early, Jennifer kept refreshing her email every few minutes and barely slept the night before results were released.' This most strongly suggests that Jennifer:
options: Always submits applications early and never sleeps well
Is highly anxious about receiving the results of her application
Will definitely be accepted because she applied early
Has received rejections from similar applications before
slides.explanation:
Phase analysis:

PHASE 1—Stated facts:
- Applied 2 weeks early
- Constantly checking email
- Couldn't sleep before results

PHASE 2—One-step inference:
Constant checking + sleep loss = anxiety about results
This is ONE logical step from observable behavior

PHASE 3—Trap elimination:

A: ✗ EXTREME LANGUAGE—'always' and 'never' unsupported. Passage describes THIS application only.

B: ✓ CORRECT—One step from evidence. Repetitive checking + inability to sleep directly suggests anxiety about results. No extreme language, fully supported.

C: ✗ FUTURE PREDICTION + FALSE CAUSATION—'definitely' unsupported. Early application doesn't guarantee acceptance.

D: ✗ OUTSIDE KNOWLEDGE—Past rejections not mentioned or implied. Adds information not in passage.

strategy_card.title: The INFER Strategy Quick Reference

steps: Draw direct line from evidence to conclusion
Verify: Would anyone reading this reach same conclusion?
Remove extreme language (always, never, all, none)
Check that inference matches passage direction

strategy_card.the_100_rule: Valid inferences are one step away from stated evidence. If you're working hard to justify an answer, it's probably wrong.

common_mistakes: Making inferences requiring multiple logical steps
Choosing answers with extreme or absolute language
Using outside knowledge instead of passage evidence
Predicting future events not supported by passage

inference_quick_reference.Valid: One step from evidence, feels obvious, no extreme language
inference_quick_reference.Extreme Language: Always, never, all, none → usually wrong
inference_quick_reference.Multiple Steps: If X, then Y, then Z → too many steps
inference_quick_reference.Outside Knowledge: Uses info not in passage → wrong

strategy_integration.key_innovation: 3-Phase INFER Strategy: Read Literally → Take One Step → Eliminate Overreach
